I remember as a child when walking in an arid area in Idaho, seeing what my parents called a 'tin can'. It was slowly breaking down with rust, much of it already nearly dissolved, the walls of the can having become as thin as paper. The can had been made several decades ago, not like a modern aluminum can whose life absent recycling would be very long indeed.

Today huge amounts of plastic waste are floating in our oceans, one estimate being a mass about the size of Texas. As our societies continue to produce staggering amounts of waste, should we not be forward looking enough to realize that many of these materials are nearly indestructible, and will take centuries if not millenia to break down.

In a better and possible world, all world governments would have strict regulations about what can be produced and the long term effect of all kinds of products on the environment. We have an obligation to those who come after us, humankind and other species as well, who deserve ‘a better world’.
